B0D57F8C03A4412DA83ACFCD2AFC81A5.description: Describe how Canadian and international copyright laws affect the lives of those who work in the jazz field.

EEB94BF9411C421A83A7ACD8D0D1087A.description: Describe and discuss music styles other than jazz from the past and/or present that may have developed as a result of contact between different cultures.

E0B01A580FE0474BA28653BED52613D4.description: Investigate the influence of jazz in Canadian musical culture (e.g., was jazz ever the ‘pop’ music in Canada, North America, or Europe?).

8D2F8B4A4DC746C1801B2C1E855E260B.description: Investigate a variety of jazz styles or genres, and explore the influence of jazz on Canadian culture, past and present.

CF9E5EFB40674EE1AB68092CB35E4EE3.description: Research career avenues in jazz and music in general.

1F768D9F1CF941E19DF27AB1E1DE13CB.description: Describe the different peoples that made up the culture of New Orleans at the start of the 20th century and the ways that these cultures influenced the development of jazz music.

78AD11A2038F4D798D33DFDEF2A44F48.description: Identify influential performers in the history of jazz (e.g., players on the level of Miles Davis, John Coltrane, Bill Evans, Elvin Jones, Louis Armstrong) players that everyone who plays jazz should know. Investigate why these performers are identified as particularly influential and listen to their music.

368BA304929248668D721ABCB53441A5.description: Demonstrate an awareness of key historical and artistic developments and trends as they relate to the eras and styles of jazz (e.g., Great Depression, WW II, swing).

879ADB1C4E7B4B6485DAA44F6D892BAF.description: Develop a jazz history timeline from about 1890 through the present, including developments in jazz music, major figures, and styles along with important world historical events.

81E4C13E39414749956B6A3D7E4508EC.description: Investigate aspects of jazz such as history, performers, styles, and eras through a variety of media.

119676BCE17C472192887A4EA54CE8FF.description: Develop (through listening) a list or understanding of the basic characteristics of different jazz styles, genres, periods, and place and implement that knowledge into practice and performance.

11A221923B5E43B98FA7BDD6ABBC33FC.description: Develop the ability to distinguish aurally the different eras, genres, styles, and feels of jazz by listening to and/or performing the representative music.

F0D36D603F3A4841A11947D94AFDBFF9.description: Cultural/Historical (CH): Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of jazz within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts.

FDFE1656A3924BA19EC0E81D5CB05BB6.description: Discuss the value of individual practice and how to practice, conduct an ongoing evaluation of the student’s personal practice skills, and implement a plan to improve.

C78B92465DF4468C9C3BE49A673F0837.description: Be accepting of appropriate critiques from others and work towards implementing the solutions to those critiques.

437C17994F3B457384269BC317050DFF.description: With direction from the teacher, critically examine and assess the student’s individual work and personal contributions to group projects/performances.

2FF5A00DBA5C456D9D28FE5CCE6D122F.description: Show respect for the personal work of self and others through appropriate critique.

4CF68A69AA3A4D89A0F220305425C7E4.description: Identify the components of a ‘professional’ attitude towards conduct, focus, and communication skills in rehearsal, preparation of materials, and presentation of products.

B66DFF3899C147CDA234856F8B5091D9.description: Discuss the challenges and importance of playing in tune with good balance and tone. Students and teachers together should develop strategies to improve the individual tuning of the students and their ensembles (e.g., who to listen to in his/her section or ensemble).

1BCA125F360E4D90B163E8928CB965DC.description: With direction from the teacher, identify the importance of and begin to implement attention to melodic phrasing, rhythmic accuracy, articulation, and responsibility for time, in the preparation and performance of jazz.

6BEB0CEDAC4F47C3BE64F21FEA43AA69.description: Know the basic functions of the student’s individual part within an ensemble by demonstrating the ability to perform those specific tasks that are particular to the instrument that the student plays in the ensemble (e.g., comping for guitar and piano, walking lines for the bass, solo chairs in the horns).

AF1DE33ECF284BB8B7D80109CAB8C650.description: Explore and begin to implement the skills, knowledge, techniques, and attitudes necessary for successful ensemble performance.

ABA5594036924C488FD9D9F7F1F0FB03.description: Recognize and discuss the value of original thought, technical proficiency, place, era, and other concepts, in the music of the great jazz performers.

FE414D765F5446529A475C943C13FED7.description: Explore the components of listening actively, continue to develop listening skills, and recognize that listening actively contributes to the authenticity of performances.

6148612E3B854F2DBACA1E76B8EC0024.description: When listening to a musical selection, discover the elements of music that may be used by a listener to help identify the style, period, composer, culture, and performer. As a class, describe and classify the music using appropriate jazz language (e.g., style, period, composer, culture, and performer).

9D059AA82C0543A8AE17A4A8AC1535E1.description: Design and implement a plan for improvement (personal and group) based on the criteria generated from listening to the great performers.

85D26B0B45574F0DA1393064D290329A.description: Generate criteria of excellence through listening to the music of the great performers, (e.g., What is it that makes the music great? What do the great performers do that the student or student’s ensemble do not?).

9A45F5CB14384BE58BBD2DB02C19D96F.description: Listen to the music of the great jazz performers.

357F0170B2664D3FA43E1C360DA5B145.description: Discover and apply the pattern of strong and weak beats that are identified with the above time signatures.

82BDE610AF7945E29AEB9AAA43F090B6.description: Listen to music and develop strategies to recognize aurally the time signature of the music, and when appropriate, clap on 2 and 4

610D31997C6144718FC8A1E2D9D00DBD.description: Identify the time signature on first hearing a piece of music, in simple time signatures such as 2/4, 3/4, and 4/4.

376BCEB9D36C4B3AB224DCF652C9CB4D.description: Identify common chord progressions including but not limited to blues changes in music performed and/or listened to (including progressions that break from the norm).

14ACA786666C44C2A24557B6FCB0CD5C.description: Individually and in groups, with help from the teacher, identify, experiment with, and purposefully use strategies to solve different challenges related to music making.

A4A7D0D0C9DA49AD98B25FBCBCBA4297.description: Explore the ability to analyze jazz music in real time while making or listening to the music.

A30B1EFA8A244906A9BEF07CFBE1A7C5.description: Discuss the history, cultural heritage, and effect of current events as these apply to the musical selection.

51618B173E0449DA8F154C39975CF4DE.description: Analyze and reflect on the melody, bass line, fills (including drums and percussion), background lines, chord progression, chord roots and sing along with the recording.

69FC8694701441A1B35C26DD70052D81.description: Analyze and reflect on just one instrument from the beginning to the end of the musical selection, (e.g., Did the player play the same way all the way through? How was it different or the same? What did he/she play that the student also might be able to play?)

2F43A20D023E4D52822DAA4EA02C5388.description: Analyze jazz performances individually and in groups, to identify performers and/or groups on recordings just by listening to the characteristic sounds or ideas presented in the music.

A699C22E87214F79833C793790CB0EBF.description: Analyze the characteristic sounds, licks, tone, and other elements of well-known players and/or groups.

CB2AF67B90254E0B90DBC5275C5D211B.description: Analyze and reflect on the structure of the chord progression and the potential development of the chord progression.

7073E911690D4598BFB4C5FD5074CFFA.description: Analyze the development of the jazz music (head, arrangement, or improvisation) as a whole or in smaller sections.

3E75301F47A54AF58825FCF0865019C1.description: Listen to jazz music and analyze form, tone, style, era, dynamics, articulation, time signature, characteristic rhythms, time, balance, blend, key, and/or pitch.

CF0D2C18732946A8A2C7244D93B2C0A9.description: Listen to jazz as a jazz performer when not personally playing the music.

A06E091F20CF4219932405B31100B2B9.description: Know, predict, and/or anticipate what is next or might be next in the music and prepare for that while performing in the moment of the music.

DA3971F30F8343758230E785E80CAB78.description: Know any special emotional context that may apply to the music, generate the appropriate emotional feeling or energy, and/or change the personal emotional state of the performer to synchronize it with the emotional context of the music being performed.

D4D05278350040B89F1ACE4005AC4E0C.description: Recall previous experiences and knowledge (in music and in life) and integrate these into solo and group jazz performances.

78867DC067CA4AF893CEFFAEB46901AF.description: Know the history, culture, style, form, and tempo of the music being performed and respond to the music (written or not written) by reading the music and/or performing the notes and/or changes appropriately.

9675D233F8EE4BA7B5D3981AF91F9DC9.description: React to the audience, to their presence (or not), body language, expressions, and their reaction to the music (e.g. applause, cheering, being asked to play quieter).

2A3F34CB833F4B378E56484B5C62C38E.description: Listen to the acoustic properties of the performing space, including the sound, tone, loudness, and reverb of the room, and adjust playing accordingly.

7B920DB9D81341A99D1B83DFC7FDEE88.description: Respond to the conductor/leader, including his/her gestures, cues, tempo, expressions, and body language.

0F9BE9F1233148F09BE82C3EB0CAE789.description: Respond to the ensemble’s response to the student’s responding to them (e.g. when the lead player starts to play out or articulate a certain way, does the band follow and does the lead player recognize it?).

D4528B7033674B5BA77020D2F09AAA48.description: Respond to the rest of the ensemble (e.g., their tone, pitch, dynamics, style, rhythm, time, balance, and blend).

1AA567FFC9FE409E82B42DFB7F9BCE45.description: Respond to qualities of personal tone such as pitch, dynamics, style, rhythm, and time.

B98512309A614FC6837BA938E7E0E337.description: Listen and respond as a jazz performer when playing jazz.

317241ED64334F4A82A03DD069C8A294.description: Critical/Responsive (CR): Students will respond to artistic expressions of their own creation and of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, creativity, research, and collaborative inquiry.

644221E52AC94194A0A6CF7401FA8CED.description: Play major, dorian, mixolydian, and blues scales in G, C, F, Bb, Eb and Ab concert.* Sight-read music at one level below the general level of the music being performed by the ensemble

FB4BAF1B01F643C4852A558D04265F19.description: Discover concepts and skills necessary to play expressively and implement through playing.

064FEAB63D574006BF632D09014AA7F8.description: Play with a tone appropriate to the style and personal development.

88916FB6FDB24561940BFB4A86F5D103.description: Generate technical inquiry questions and take action on the findings of the inquiry (e.g., “What can I do to get better?” or “How could I change this performance, paper, or arrangement?”).

365D8616998143828073028265FF0CC3.description: Demonstrate and record technical development, with assistance from the teacher, and develop strategies to improve.

45431B0049294F8C815E87C8E83C690A.description: Show growth in individual instrumental techniques and knowledge of the elements of music and apply these to create or show a musical product.

1BDCBFC3B7834122B138AAF26FF478C8.description: Begin to use jazz vocabulary to relate jazz theory to personal musical performance (see Jazz Glossary).

8DB395CDD2BA4856AF5578DDDCFDBC7D.description: Identify the standards of notation in jazz music that are different from traditional ”classical” notation (e.g., falls, doits, turns, and hats, as well as notation conventions such as how off-beat quarter notes should be written).

32BE05F6506F4FAA813A6F12F34AA0CF.description: Know, describe, and use in performance the standard notation conventions such as note durations up to 16th notes, codas, D.S.s, and dynamic markings.

31075A6B747344C19C7DD10152E6C83E.description: Describe conventions regarding jazz articulation and use those conventions in performance.

C64E4AF7C641491CBF69BDDD0EAFE5ED.description: As a class and with help from the teacher design, implement, and evaluate a personal plan to improve individual performance process, and to enhance knowledge and understandings of jazz (e.g., as part of the process of improvement, include recording and listening back to the performances, practices, and/or rehearsals).

E6B0124A18BD4D0F912A05085F2EF4DF.description: Recognize and define musical forms emphasizing blues form, in music that is listened to and/or performed.

35694904CA4347C280DDD8F251C6CECA.description: Identify different elements of music such as articulation, rhythm, beat, metre, time placement, and tone that help create a jazz style and apply this knowledge while music making.

C4B3C722F67341A48A73A2737A9022DF.description: Prepare, rehearse, and perform music in a jazz style in solo, small group, or large ensemble settings

5DC69C1ECC3A46739F207572AC29596C.description: Explore the elements of jazz theory through personal musical performance.

EE7BCFAF522F4821B48636E142E93B2F.description: Demonstrate, through writing, describing, and/or playing, the understanding of jazz theory including: 7th chords , modes of major and minor scales and blues form.

CDA8F4952C204570BAEF4172E34C02BA.description: Improvise to show the beginning of understanding the function of guide tones within a musical form or chord progression.

EFCE3FBDC9104B6997D263233EE5B1BE.description: Take personal and musical risks by trying new ways to express oneself in the jazz idiom, using new ideas, new concepts, and a variety of styles.

0BD6152D793E41039909D8457574EF56.description: Exhibit improvement and growth in the presentation and construction of improvised solos in a performance setting.

67C606F85FE54EA39129A9CA53D83A99.description: Create simple, short three or four note jazz licks and develop these licks by methods such as: transposing, transforming, adding single notes, decorating and connecting licks with segments of scales.

D5DBE3E6479D4A18830BCD788AD8D387.description: Play and/or transcribe recorded music of recognized performers through methods such as: • play blues heads and simple and more complex jazz tunes by ear sing roots of the chord progression of the solo, call and response with the teacher (or other students) • sing and/or play along with solo, sing the solo being studied without listening to the recording at the same time, notate the solo including elements such as form, chord changes, pitches, rhythms articulations, and dynamics and start with short sections such as a few bars or a single lick, and gradually increase the length and complexity of the selection.

FEF1314646834F3583E02CC41282D3E2.description: Identify and analyze musical events within a solo or composition (e.g., shout chorus, form, dynamics, pitches, changes, articulation).

1C33BCB08E4948D08ED04FFBE6F69866.description: Improvise in a jazz style on an instrument exploring understanding of applicable jazz theory.

F06F5ABA33E142D487084CB2592E7EFB.description: Creative/Productive (CP): Students will inquire, create, and communicate through jazz.
